body_html:
THIS IS IMPORTANT BUT ONLY PART OF THE PROBLEM
Read on and follow instructions below then refer to the next issue

You are correct thank you very much.

Let me explicit a bit your solution because I nearly failed to grasp it and this can be useful for future readership and eventual documentation.

If one docker pulls a developer image, it will contain the full tensorflow source code in addition to the binary. So for example let's docker pull tensorflow/tensorflow:1.3.0-devel-py3, then one should be able to run parameterized_docker_build.sh in the /tensorflow/tensorflow/tools/docker folder just fine.

The smallest command line to generate a docker image will then be:
docker run -it tensorflow/tensorflow:right tag

Port mapping at 8888 -p 8888:8888 in the strict context of this question is nice to have.

body:
**THIS IS IMPORTANT BUT ONLY PART OF THE PROBLEM**
**Read on and follow instructions below then refer to the [next issue](https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/issues/13379)**

You are correct thank you very much.

Let me explicit a bit your solution because I nearly failed to grasp it and this can be useful for future readership and eventual documentation.

If one docker pulls a developer image, it will contain the full tensorflow source code in addition to the binary. So for example let's docker pull tensorflow/tensorflow:1.3.0-devel-py3, then one should be able to run parameterized_docker_build.sh in the /tensorflow/tensorflow/tools/docker folder just  fine.

The smallest command line to generate a docker image will then be:
`docker run -it tensorflow/tensorflow:`[right tag](https://hub.docker.com/r/tensorflow/tensorflow/tags/)

Port mapping at 8888 `-p 8888:8888` in the strict context of this question is nice to have.
